question.question-text: What major problem in the construction of the transcontinental railroad does the professor mainly discuss?
question.explain-text: In the lecture, the professor states that today we'll focus on the tremendous financial difficulties of building the railroad and that the most difficult task…was funding. This means that the primary problem the professor is discussing in this lecture is finances. The third answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: Why couldn't the federal government completely fund the construction of the railroad?

answer-list.answer-text: Congress voted down the Railroad Act.
Over $100 million was needed to complete the project.
The government only had $48,000 available to fund the railroad.
The railroad cost more than the entire federal budget.

question.explain-text: In the lecture, the professor states that the railroad would cost…over $100 million and it was almost twice as much as the federal budget at the time. This means that over $100 million was needed to complete the project and that the railroad cost more than the entire federal budget. The second and last answers are therefore the best answers to this question.

question.question-text: Why did the railroad companies spend thousands of dollars developing businesses out West when they lacked financial resources to build the track?

answer-list.answer-text: They wanted to demonstrate the usefulness of a transcontinental railroad.
The government required them to develop businesses along railroad lines.
They needed more refueling stops for the trains in that area.
The businesses generated money for the railroad.

question.explain-text: In the lecture, the professor states that to raise funds for the railroads, railroad companies found a number of ways to raise funds; one was to make businesses dependent on the railroad and that the railroad companies…forced them to pay outrageous prices for the use of the railroad. This means that the businesses generated money for the railroad. The last answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: What incorrect information did the railroad companies use to get more money than they should have from the government?

answer-list.answer-text: They misrepresented the location of a mountain range.
They misrepresented who actually built the railroads.
They misrepresented the date when the project was finished.
They misrepresented the location of Promontory, Utah.

question.explain-text: In the lecture, the professor mentions that federal loans paid triple the money for tracks laid on mountainous terrain and that Central Pacific hired a geologist who would misrepresent the location of the Sierra Mountains. This means that the railroad companies gave incorrect information when they misrepresented the location of a mountain range to get more money. The first answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: The professor mentions several categories of raising funds and provides examples of these categories. Indicate for each example which category it belongs to.

answer-text.exp:
Funds provided by
the Railroad Act

explain-list.explain-text: The professor states that railroad companies spent thousands of dollars to attract...farmers...and then forced them to pay outrageous prices for the use of the railroad. From this, it can be determined that farmers' goods shipped by rail are an example of rail-dependent businesses. You should therefore click in the second column.

The professor states that the government agreed to pay $48,000 instead of $16,000 per mile for 24 miles of flat land outside of Sacramento, California. From this, it can be determined that rails built near Sacramento are an example of unethical means. You should therefore click in the third column.

The professor states that there was some federal funding available through the Railroad Act. From this, it can be determined that funds provided by the Railroad Act are an example of federal funds. You should therefore click in the first column.

question.question-text: What can be concluded about the way that the transcontinental railroad was funded?

answer-list.answer-text: The problems in constructing the transcontinental railroad made it unsuccessful.
Those who caused the problems in the construction of the transcontinental railroad were eventually held responsible for their actions.
Though there were problems finding investors to fund the transcontinental railroad, finding government funding was not a problem.
The railroads did not always act honorably in building the transcontinental railroad.

question.explain-text: In the lecture, the professor states that the railroad companies involved in the building of the transcontinental railroad weren't always exactly aboveboard in their handling of this project, that these businessmen, farmers, and craftsmen who were lured to the West with promises of success soon found themselves…unable to make much of a living because of the high prices they had to pay to the railroads to stay in business, and that because both the Union Pacific and Central Pacific were desperate and greedy, they turned to increasingly unethical means of obtaining funds. From this, it can be determined that the railroads did not always act honorably in building the transcontinental railroad. The last answer is therefore the best answer to this question.
